What is a global payments SaaS for banks?
text:
A global payments SaaS (Software-as-a-Service) for banks is a cloud-based platform that allows banks to process cross-border payments efficiently and securely. It typically includes features such as payment processing, compliance checks, foreign exchange, and fraud detection.

Some of the features that a bank would want from a global payments SaaS include:

Multiple Payment Options: The SaaS should support various payment methods, such as SWIFT, SEPA, and local clearing systems.

Compliance and Regulatory Checks: The SaaS should perform KYC (Know Your Customer) and AML (Anti-Money Laundering) checks to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

Real-time Payment Tracking: The SaaS should provide real-time updates on payment status and transaction details to the bank and its customers.

Currency Conversion: The SaaS should support real-time currency conversion and provide competitive exchange rates.

Fraud Detection and Prevention: The SaaS should include advanced fraud detection and prevention measures to ensure the security of transactions.

Automated Reconciliation: The SaaS should have automated reconciliation capabilities to help banks streamline their back-office operations.

Scalability: The SaaS should be scalable and able to handle a growing volume of transactions as the bank's business expands.

API Integration: The SaaS should have an API that allows banks to integrate with other systems and applications seamlessly.

Customization: The SaaS should be customizable to meet the specific needs of each bank.

A global payments SaaS for banks should be user-friendly, reliable, and cost-effective while providing comprehensive features to process cross-border payments efficiently and securely.

Show HN: Real-time emotional subtitles for Apple Watch
text:
I made a tonal analysis app with the goal of translating emotions across neurotypes and accents to improve emotional communication.

Our ML model runs on edge on the Apple Watch and was trained on representative datasets of the vocal diversity of North American speakers, taking into account race, gender, geography, age, and neurotype.

More about VIBES:

Introducing Vibes for Apple Watch! Vibes reads emotions during conversation to help improve emotional communication and shared understanding. Vibes is the first emotional subtitle app for Apple Watch, buzzing emotions with real-time haptic and visual feedback. Vibes was created by Valence Vibrations to improve emotional connection and friendship across diverse communities of people, while supporting the power of each person’s unique voice. You may even understand your own emotions better via Vibes.

Vibes only uses on-device processing, so all vocal data and emotional classifications cannot be accessed by Vibes or a third party. Vibes currently only supports North American English speakers and Apple Watch Series 4 or later. Other languages and devices are coming soon.

We have a free 1 week trial active and I'm happy to extend it for folks in this community if there's interest.

Ask HN: Why isn't distributed scraping used on social media sites
text:
Suppose I build an extension for LinkedIn where it adds some functionality on LinkedIn user profile pages. This means the extension can see the complete profile of every LinkedIn User that the chrome extension user interacts with.

I can then send this data to myself and scrape a good chunk of LinkedIn. Apart from this being illegal, Why isn't this done yet?
